channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: This Michigan city goes wild for its public library's Summer Game
item.description: Summer for thousands of people in Ann Arbor means scavenging for hidden codes around the city and reading books to collect points. It's been a triumph for the public library that runs it.

item.title: NFL bans smelling salts during games over safety concerns
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Dr. Robert Cantu, medical director and director of clinical research at the Cantu Concussion Center at Emerson Hospital, about the NFL banning teams from providing smelling salts on game days.

item.title: Hundreds of former Israeli military and security leaders urge Trump to end Gaza war
item.description: More than 500 former officials who once led Israel's military and security agencies are asking President Trump to help stop the war in Gaza. NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with one of them.

item.title: Illinois Gov. Pritzker on why his state is hosting Texas state lawmakers
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with J.B. Pritzker, the governor of Illinois, about hosting a group of Texas state lawmakers as they protest a partisan redistricting effort in their state.

item.title: A Texas Republican state lawmaker on the fight for redistricting
item.description: Texas Republican Tom Oliverson about what's next in the redistricting fight that is going down in the Lone Star state.

item.title: When wildfires make the air smoky, here's how to protect your health
item.description: Smoke from Canadian wildfires continues to bring poor air quality into the Northeast U.S. and the Upper Midwest. And the exposure to wildfire smoke remains a growing health problem.

item.title: How the Trump administration is rolling back access to birth control in the U.S.
item.description: Contraception is routine for many Americans – and people across political parties agree that it should be legal and accessible. But the Trump administration is walking back access for some people.

item.title: What one parent did to rescue their child from online violent extremism
item.description: Children are increasingly being targeted online by violent, predatory networks that groom them into harmful behaviors. One mother whose son fell under their influence shares her family's experience.

item.title: How many steps do you need to stay healthy?
item.description: Most of us have heard you need 10,000 steps a day to stave off health problems, but new research is finding that number is not necessary -- though more is always better.

item.title: These researchers are using radiation to protect rhinos
item.description: We speak with James Larkin, the head of a project in South Africa that's experimenting with using radiation to prevent rhino poaching. They sedate the animals and inject radiation into their horns.
